perturbation.original_text: Section 6.1 Obligations of Depomed. In accordance with the provisions of this Agreement and all applicable Legal Requirements, Depomed shall, at its cost and expense, use reasonable best efforts to perform or cause to be performed all Product manufacture, labeling, packaging, warehousing, distribution and return, order entry, customer services and all other activities to supply and distribute the Product in the Territory in order to fill orders for Product conforming to the then-current Volume Forecast in a timely and efficient manner. From and after the completion of the sixth full calendar month following the Promotion Commencement Date, Depomed shall use commercially reasonable efforts to maintain at least one month's safety stock of Product ("Safety Stock") to address unanticipated changes in demand for the Product (calculated on the basis of the Volume Forecast contained in the then-current Annual Plan).
perturbation.changed_text: Section 6.1 Obligations of Depomed. In accordance with the provisions of this Agreement and all applicable Legal Requirements, Depomed shall, at its cost and expense, use reasonable best efforts to perform or cause to be performed all Product manufacture, labeling, packaging, warehousing, distribution and return, order entry, customer services and all other activities to supply and distribute the Product in the Territory in order to fill orders for Product conforming to the then-current Volume Forecast in a timely and efficient manner. Depomed may, at its discretion, maintain a safety stock of Product ("Safety Stock") to address unanticipated changes in demand for the Product (calculated on the basis of the Volume Forecast contained in the then-current Annual Plan).
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that Depomed 'shall' use reasonable best efforts to perform all product manufacturing and distribution activities, and 'shall' maintain a safety stock after a certain period. The modified version changes this obligation to 'may' maintain a safety stock. This creates a contradiction: While Depomed is initially obligated to ensure supply, a later clause gives them the discretion to not maintain safety stock, potentially leading to supply failures. It introduces uncertainty about the continuous availability of the product, impacting King's promotional efforts.

perturbation.changed_text:
Section 4.1 Product Promotion.

(a) Subject to applicable Legal Requirements, as well as the provisions of this Agreement, King may, from and after the Promotion Commencement Date, at its discretion and expense, decide whether or not to Promote the Product within the Territory in accordance with the Launch Plan or Annual Plan (the "Promotional Effort"). For purposes of the preceding sentence, King's commercially reasonable efforts shall mean, until [***], at least the same
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates that King 'shall' use commercially reasonable efforts to promote the product. The modified text changes this to King 'may' promote the product 'at its discretion'. This introduces a direct contradiction: the agreement initially requires promotion efforts, but later grants King the option to not promote the product at all. This would make it difficult to enforce the initial promotion obligations as King can simply choose not to promote.

perturbation.original_text:
Section 4.4 Promotional Materials; Educational Materials.

(a) Subject to Sections 4.4(b), 4.4(c) and 4.9, King shall, [***], create, develop, produce or otherwise obtain, and utilize sales, promotional, advertising, marketing, educational and training materials ("Promotional Materials") which are necessary to support fully the Promotional Effort for the Product. Such Promotional Materials may include, by way of example, detailing aids; leave items; journal advertising; educational programs; formulary binders; appropriate reprints and reprint carriers; product monographs; patient support kits; convention exhibit materials; direct mail; market research survey and analysis; training materials; and scripts for telemarketing and teleconferences. All Promotional Materials used by the King Sales Force or bearing the King Trademarks will be subject to the review and approval of the King CCC. All Promotional Materials developed by King hereunder shall prominently display such Depomed Trademark(s) as shall be specified by Depomed to King following its review of the applicable prototype in accordance with Section 4.4(b).
perturbation.changed_text:
Section 4.4 Promotional Materials; Educational Materials.

(a) Subject to Sections 4.4(b), 4.4(c) and 4.9, King may, if it chooses, create, develop, produce or otherwise obtain, and utilize sales, promotional, advertising, marketing, educational and training materials ("Promotional Materials") which are necessary to support fully the Promotional Effort for the Product. Promotional Materials are optional. If King develops materials, such Promotional Materials may include, by way of example, detailing aids; leave items; journal advertising; educational programs; formulary binders; appropriate reprints and reprint carriers; product monographs; patient support kits; convention exhibit materials; direct mail; market research survey and analysis; training materials; and scripts for telemarketing and teleconferences. If King chooses to make Promotional Materials, all Promotional Materials used by the King Sales Force or bearing the King Trademarks will be subject to the review and approval of the King CCC. All Promotional Materials developed by King hereunder shall prominently display such Depomed Trademark(s) as shall be specified by Depomed to King following its review of the applicable prototype in accordance with Section 4.4(b).
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that King 'shall' create promotional materials to support the promotional effort. The modified text introduces 'may, if it chooses' and 'Promotional Materials are optional.' This is a direct contradiction: the initial obligation to create materials is undermined by granting King the option to forgo materials. This creates uncertainty about the extent to which the product will be actively promoted and makes it challenging to enforce the original promotion requirement.
